>From: Derek James <djames@...>
>
>But again, if we're just talking about a single neuron, why not just
>allow for a single mutation to bring about that new functionality,
>instead of keeping redundant features around, waiting for them to be
>connected?  The former is much more efficient than the latter.
>
>If you're talking about just connecting a single neuron into the
>network that was just hanging around unconnected beforehand, that's
>logically equivalent to mutating a new neuron and two connections
>between two existing neurons, right?  Why not add this type of
>mutation to your GA, rather than have a whole bunch of neurons that
>don't do *anything* until a connection mutates to link them up with
>the rest of the functioning network?

I would think that, because you are splitting an existing connection, you 
don't have things that are just 'hanging out there' unless you happen to 
support deleting connections.  Since Ken's NEAT doesn't do that, it's a moot 
point.  With the current way that things are designed in NEAT, *every* node 
is ultimately connected to both the input and the output, so every node DOES 
contribute at least a little to the overall fitness.  If the weights are 
such that their impact is minimal, future mutations and crossovers could 
change that at any time.

If you do support deleting connections, that changes the dynamic a lot.  For 
one thing, you may have to deal with orphaned nodes.  If you have a low 
mutation rate and you spend a lot of time evaluating lots of different 
possibilities, then deleting most likely takes you back to somewhere you've 
already been once upon a time.  If your mutation rate is higher, then that 
'going back' might actually take you back somewhere that you haven't been 
yet.  Somewhere that you wouldn't have been able to get to, because you had 
already passed it.  But then again, since simple genomes are preserved, you 
might well have found it eventually.
